etymologies: Middle English: from Middle Dutch rec, Middle Low German rek ‘horizontal bar or shelf’, probably from recken ‘to stretch, reach’ (possibly the source of rack (sense 1 of the verb))

notes.text: The relationship between the forms rack and wrack is complicated. The most common noun sense of rack, ‘a framework for holding and storing things’, is always spelled rack, never wrack. In the phrase rack something up the word is also always spelled rack. Figurative senses of the verb, deriving from the type of torture in which someone is stretched on a rack, can, however, be spelled either rack or wrack: thus racked with guilt or wracked with guilt; rack your brains or wrack your brains. In addition, the phrase rack and ruin can also be spelled wrack and ruin

definitions: a framework, typically with rails, bars, hooks, or pegs, for holding or storing things
shortDefinitions: framework for holding or storing things

definitions: a stack of digital effects units for a guitar or other instrument.
shortDefinitions: stack of digital effects units for a guitar or other instrument

definitions: a vertically barred frame or wagon for holding animal fodder
shortDefinitions: vertically barred frame for holding animal fodder

definitions: a cogged or toothed bar or rail engaging with a wheel or pinion, or using pegs to adjust the position of something
shortDefinitions: cogged or toothed bar or rail engaging with wheel or pinion

definitions: an instrument of torture consisting of a frame on which the victim was stretched by turning rollers to which the wrists and ankles were tied.
shortDefinitions: instrument of torture consisting of frame on which victim was stretched by turning rollers to which

crossReferenceMarkers: Compare with frame (sense 7 of the noun)
definitions: a triangular structure for positioning the balls in pool.
shortDefinitions: triangular structure for positioning balls in pool

definitions: a single game of snooker.
shortDefinitions: single game of pool

definitions: a woman's breasts

examples.text: Arnie's woman is kinda bossy, but she's got a nice rack

shortDefinitions: woman's breasts

definitions: a set of antlers

examples.text: moose have the most impressive racks of all the antlered animals

shortDefinitions: set of antlers

definitions: a bed.
shortDefinitions: bed

notes.text: The relationship between the forms rack and wrack is complicated. The most common noun sense of rack, ‘a framework for holding and storing things’, is always spelled rack, never wrack. In the phrase rack something up the word is also always spelled rack. Figurative senses of the verb, deriving from the type of torture in which someone is stretched on a rack, can, however, be spelled either rack or wrack: thus racked with guilt or wracked with guilt; rack your brains or wrack your brains. In addition, the phrase rack and ruin can also be spelled wrack and ruin

definitions: cause extreme physical or mental pain to; subject to extreme stress
shortDefinitions: cause extreme pain, anguish, or distress to

definitions: torture (someone) on the rack.
shortDefinitions: torture someone on rack

definitions: place in or on a rack

examples.text: the shoes were racked neatly beneath the dresses

shortDefinitions: place in or on rack

definitions: raise (rent) above a fair or normal amount.
shortDefinitions: raise rent above fair or normal amount

definitions: a horse's gait in which both hoofs on either side in turn are lifted almost simultaneously, and all four hoofs are off the ground together at certain moments.
shortDefinitions: horse's gait in which both hoofs on either side in turn are lifted simultaneously, and all four hoofs are off ground together at certain moments

definitions: (of a horse) move with a rack gait.
shortDefinitions: (of horse) move with such gait

definitions: a large cut of meat, typically lamb, that includes the front ribs.
shortDefinitions: joint of meat that includes front ribs

etymologies: late 15th century: from Provençal arracar, from raca ‘stems and husks of grapes, dregs’

definitions: draw off (wine, beer, etc.) from the sediment in the barrel

examples.text: the wine is racked off into large oak casks

shortDefinitions: draw off (wine, beer, etc.) from sediment in barrel

etymologies: Middle English (denoting a rush or collision): probably of Scandinavian origin; compare with Norwegian and Swedish dialect rak ‘wreckage’, from reka ‘to drive’

definitions: a mass of high, thick, fast-moving clouds

examples.text: there was a thin moon, a rack of cloud

shortDefinitions: mass of high, fast-moving clouds

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

definitions: (of a cloud) be driven before the wind

examples.text: a thin shred of cloud racking across the moon

shortDefinitions: (of cloud) be driven before wind
